dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, remember early in the Ukraine invasion, like, the estimates for rebuilding were already pretty massive?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, remember early in the Ukraine invasion, like, the estimates for rebuilding were already pretty massive?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I think it was, uh, what, 200 to 500 billion dollars? And Europe was kinda, like, called on to spearhead that effort.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I think it was, uh, what, two hundred to five hundred billion dollars? And Europe was kinda, like, called on to spearhead that effort.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shortly after Russias invasion, my co-authors and I estimated that it would cost roughly 200-500 billion ($220-550 billion) to rebuild the country and called for Europe to spearhead the recovery effort.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But after more than 500 days of, you know, just immense destruction, that number's, uh, probably at least doubled now. And this article really hammers home that Europe *has* to step up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But after more than five hundred days of, you know, just immense destruction, that number's, uh, probably at least doubled now. And this article really hammers home that Europe has to step up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After more than 500 days of death and destruction, the projected costs have probably at least doubled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting, because you'd think, okay, the US is also deeply invested, right? But the article makes a really strong case for *Europe* leading this. Why do you think that is?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting, because you'd think, okay, the U S is also deeply invested, right? But the article makes a really strong case for Europe leading this. Why do you think that is?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the United States is also deeply invested in Ukraines future, as its massive economic and military support for the country has shown, there are several reasons why Europe must take the lead in coordinating and financing the countrys postwar recovery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, one big reason they point out is that Europe's interests are just more closely aligned with Ukraine's. Like, Europe gained way more from the fall of the Berlin Wall than the US did, and they have far more to lose if things go sideways now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, one big reason they point out is that Europe's interests are just more closely aligned with Ukraine's. Like, Europe gained way more from the fall of the Berlin Wall than the U S did, and they have far more to lose if things go sideways now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: First, Europes interests are more closely aligned with Ukraines. While the US benefited enormously from the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, European countries reaped far greater rewards. Similarly, Europe has more to lose from a return to the pre-war status quo, not to mention from the looming threat of nuclear escalation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And there's also the whole US political dynamic. Even if military support stays, um, you know, after the 2024 election... financial support might just, like, fade away because of populism focusing domestically.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And there's also the whole U S political dynamic. Even if military support stays, um, you know, after the twenty twenty four election... financial support might just, like, fade away because of populism focusing domestically.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Second, Europeans must realize that even if US military support for Europe and Ukraine remains intact following the 2024 presidential election a big if, given the current state of US politics Americas enthusiasm for long-term financial support will likely fade, regardless of the outcome. Both Democrats and Republicans are increasingly embracing populist stances, and todays populists focus mostly on domestic issues, with little concern for the rest of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Both Democrats and Republicans are increasingly embracing those populist stances. And then, Ukraine already has EU candidate status, right? So it's already considered an integral part of Europe. The EU needs to, uh, expedite that process.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Both Democrats and Republicans are increasingly embracing those populist stances. And then, Ukraine already has E U candidate status, right? So it's already considered an integral part of Europe. The E U needs to, uh, expedite that process.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Democrats and Republicans are increasingly embracing populist stances... Third, the European Union has already granted Ukraine candidate status, thereby acknowledging that the country is an integral part of Europe and should be part of the bloc. Given that Ukraine will most likely require substantial technical assistance to improve its governance standards and meet the conditions for accession, the EU must do all it can to expedite this process.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which means a lot of technical assistance too, to get their governance up to par. [interrupts] But I think the most striking point for me was about Europe's defense spending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which means a lot of technical assistance too, to get their governance up to par. But I think the most striking point for me was about Europe's defense spending.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given that Ukraine will most likely require substantial technical assistance to improve its governance standards and meet the conditions for accession, the EU must do all it can to expedite this process.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the free-riding point? Yeah, that's huge. The US spends, what, twice as much as EU members on national defense as a share of GDP? If Europe just, like, raised their spending, they could easily fund Ukraine's reconstruction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the free-riding point? Yeah, that's huge. The U S spends, what, twice as much as E U members on national defense as a share of G D P? If Europe just, like, raised their spending, they could easily fund Ukraine's reconstruction.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US currently spends twice as much as EU member states on national defense as a share of GDP. ... Conversely, if Europe raised spending to US levels, it would be spending at least $300 billion per year more, easily enough to pay for reconstructing Ukraine and much more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Easily! I mean, it's hundreds of billions more annually. And you look at reports, like the one from France's National Assembly, talking about exhausting ammunition in weeks... it's just not inspiring much confidence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Easily! I mean, it's hundreds of billions more annually. And you look at reports, like the one from France's National Assembly, talking about exhausting ammunition in weeks... it's just not inspiring much confidence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But a report by Frances National Assembly in February, which suggests the country would exhaust its existing ammunition within weeks in the event of an intense armed conflict, does not inspire much confidence in European countries military readiness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really highlights that, um, historical tendency for larger countries to bear a disproportionate share of the costs for the common good, like Olson and Zeckhauser argued. It explains why the US often ends up footing the bill.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really highlights that, um, historical tendency for larger countries to bear a disproportionate share of the costs for the common good, like Olson and Zeckhauser argued. It explains why the U S often ends up footing the bill.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In their brilliant 1966 paper An Economic Theory of Alliances, economists Mancur Olson and Richard Zeckhauser argued that larger countries often bear a disproportionate share of the costs associated with actions that serve the common good. ... But it does offer insight into why the US often ends up footing the bill for other countries national-defense needs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And even with the recent EU pledge of 50 billion by 2027, um, only a third of that is outright grants. The rest are loans Ukraine will likely be unable to repay. [interrupts] It's just not enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And even with the recent E U pledge of fifty billion by twenty twenty seven, um, only a third of that is outright grants. The rest are loans Ukraine will likely be unable to repay. It's just not enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the EU has recently pledged to provide Ukraine with an additional 50 billion by 2027, only a third of this sum will be given as outright grants. The rest will be provided as loans that Ukraine will most likely be unable to repay.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's really not. And this article, uh, I think it really drives home that Europe has this historic responsibility to lead this effort. Even if it means, you know, higher debt or slower growth at home.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's really not. And this article, uh, I think it really drives home that Europe has this historic responsibility to lead this effort. Even if it means, you know, higher debt or slower growth at home.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But European countries must come to terms with their historic responsibility to lead this effort, even if it means higher debt and slower growth for their own economies in the future.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a massive undertaking, but it's, like, pretty crucial for their own future stability and, uh, security, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a massive undertaking, but it's, like, pretty crucial for their own future stability and, uh, security, really.
